user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachObjectOfType:
```c
void OS_ForEachObjectOfType(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr,
                            void *callback_arg)
{
    OS_object_iter_t    iter;
    OS_creator_filter_t filter;

    filter.creator_id    = creator_id;
    filter.user_callback = callback_ptr;
    filter.user_arg      = callback_arg;

    if (OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ForEachFilterCreator, &filter, idtype, &iter) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_ForEachDoCallback);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachObjectOfType:
typedef void (*OS_ArgCallback_t)(osal_id_t object_id, void *arg)
...
typedef struct
{
    osal_id_t        creator_id;
    OS_ArgCallback_t user_callback;
    void *           user_arg;
} OS_creator_filter_t
...
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
...
int32 OS_ForEachDoCallback(osal_id_t obj_id, void *ref)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /* Just invoke the user callback */
    filter->user_callback(obj_id, filter->user_arg);
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t matchfunc, void *matcharg, osal_objtype_t objtype,
                              OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    iter->match = matchfunc;
    iter->arg   = matcharg;
    iter->limit = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(objtype);
    iter->base  = &OS_common_table[OS_GetBaseForObjectType(objtype)];

    return OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, objtype, &iter->token);
}
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(OS_object_iter_t *iter, int32 (*func)(osal_id_t, void *))
{
    int32 status;

    /*
     * This needs to temporarily unlock the global,
     * call the handler function, then re-lock.
     */
    OS_Unlock_Global(&iter->token);
    status = func(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(&iter->token), iter->arg);
    OS_Lock_Global(&iter->token);

    return status;
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(&iter->token);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    OS_common_record_t * base;
    OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t match;
    void *               arg;
    osal_index_t         limit;
    OS_object_token_t    token;
} OS_object_iter_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_objtype_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The MISRA C Rule 8.13 concern is that pointers which are not modified through the pointer should be declared to point to const-qualified types. The fragments listed above all involve functions or data structures that currently accept or store plain void * (or non-const typed) pointers but are used in the code as read-only references to the filter/context or are passed to match/callback functions without being modified. These are the places most likely to benefit from changing the pointer types to const-qualified pointer types (for example, changing the match-argument and iterator arg fields to const void *, and making the match/callback first-parameter const when the function does not modify the referenced object). Other code fragments were not included because they either already use const where appropriate (e.g. the record parameter in OS_ForEachFilterCreator is const OS_common_record_t *), or they represent user-facing callback signatures and storage (OS_ArgCallback_t, OS_creator_filter_t.user_arg, the user_callback itself, and the user-supplied callback_arg passed into OS_ForEachObjectOfType) that must remain plain void * to allow the user callback to modify the user-supplied context if desired. Also, stack-local write accesses (for example the local variable 'filter' in OS_ForEachObjectOfType which is explicitly assigned to) are intentionally non-const because they are initialized/modified before being used. Finally, some pointers (such as iter->base) refer to global/modifiable object tables; whether these can be const depends on whether callers or macros (e.g. OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) require mutable access, so they were not flagged here to avoid false positives.
